Description: Digital images of Pekerjaan di dunia ini atas selapan perkara; pertama akal, kedua ilmu, ketiga cerdik, keempat cendakia, kelima 'arif, keenam budiman, ketujuh bijaksana, keselapan berbudi.  The headings are then followed by definitions of each, e.g. bermula arti akal itu memeliharakan ia akan diri, and then followed by longer expositions upon each heading, e.g. Pascal yang pertama pada menyatakan akal atau kelebihannya, 'The first exposition, on the consciousness or its advantages'. This text is followed by a series of mystical drawings The label on the back cover gives the name of the owner (and most likely the writer) as Syaikh abdul Majid of Lubuk Lundur, with a date of 1360 (1941/1942AD): Inilah keterangan surat buku besar saya empunya atau memiliki gelar serta nama Syaikh Abdul Majid Lubuk Lundur adanya sanat 1360. The original manuscript measures 22 x 34 cm, and the text block 19 x 29 cm. It is written in blue and black ink, on locally produced paper, and has a brown paper binding. The manuscript is 37 pages long, and contains illuminations and illustrations. The original suffers from staining and insect damage. Description: Digital images of a compendium of texts, mostly on Islamic matters: Fiqh, Adat-Istiadat Minangkabu, Hisab, Tarekat Nashabandiyah, Sejarah Nabi, dan lain-lain. Concerns Islamic laws and ritual obligations, Minangkabau customs, Sufism, histories of the prophets, Admonitions for women. There is a date of 1338 (1919/1920 AD) at the end of the manuscript, most probably added by a later owner The manuscript measures 15.5 x 22.5 cm; the text block 8.5 x 15.5 cm; black and red ink on European and local paper, Minangkabau-style leather binding, 229 folios. The manuscript cover is black leather, constructed in the South Asian Muslim style. The manuscript is quite heavily annotated in a number of hands (including in Latin script), and with a variety of inks and pencils. On folio 158, ink from an annotation on the recto has shown through on the verso, partially obscuring the original text [images 316 and 317]. The manuscript suffers from staining, mould and insect damage.
